relation: Course introduction and timeline; Bird identification (Optics, Guides and Notes. Homework: Sibley Field Guide pags. 10-17)
Topography and Field Marks (Homework: Sibley Field Guide pags. 18-24); Feet, Beaks and Body Form; Field exercises, start project thinking
Field research techniques, hypotheses testing, study design, and data analysis
Survey of local birds (Pink Ravine), Review, Project guidelines discussion and selection (written ideas)
Anderson et al. 1979 Banding demo, Pomfret Center, Connecticut Audubon Society
Ortega & Capen 1999, Survey of local birds (Mansfield hollow), Field notebooks (First Submission)
Individual project data collection I (Methods adjustment)
Memorial day: Independent project data collection (Final)
Survey of local birds. Field notebooks (Final Submission)
Review session in preparation for the final; Sound guide to the birds of campus; MEDIA PROJECT FINAL SUBMISSION
FINAL EXAM; Instructor evaluations; Media Projects

textBeforeTable: Tentative* schedule o Sunscreen o Insect repellent (ticks, mosquitoes) o Birding by Ear: Eastern and Central North America o Sibley’s birding basics • Recommended o Closed-toe shoes (no sandals) or hiking boots, & proper outdoor clothing (poison ivy, weather) o Field notepad/notebook ( Basic guidelines) o Binoculars (available from us if you don’t have any) o The Sibley Field Guide to the Birds of Eastern North America • Required Course Materials ➢ Improve collaboration skills ➢ Develop a research project ➢ Learn and apply basic field techniques, study design, and data analysis ➢ Learn how to take field notes ➢ Acquire bird identification skills Course Objectives Office hours: variable & flexible (call, email, drop by) Phone: 860-486-0309 Office: Biol/Pharm 404 Instructor: Alejandro Rico Meets: M-F, 8 am to 11 am, TLS 181 Intensive Summer Session, May 12th - 30th, 2014 EEB 3898: Field Methods in Ornithology Revision as of 19:24, 29 May 2014 • MANUAL OF ORNITHOLOGY (Yale Univ.), by N.S. Proctor and
textAfterTable: *: Schedule is subject to change pending weather conditions, or unforeseen birding and research opportunities. Grading Exams: May 21st (MIDTERM) [50 points]; May 30th (FINAL) [50 points] Project Proposal Presentation: May 20th (Intro and Methods) [25 points]; Media Project: May 29th [100 points] Field Notebook Submissions: May 19th (First) [20 points]; May 28th (Final) [25 points] Field trips = Birding exercises (5 points each): Dates will be weather dependent [30 points] Total: [300 points] Grading scale: A = 100-90%, B = 89-80%, C = 79-70%, D = 69-60%, F = 59-0%. Plus/minus system will be used for the final grade. Additional References & Websites • Local Birds ID tool: http://www.whatbird.com/Expert/Expert.aspx • MANUAL OF ORNITHOLOGY (Yale Univ.), by N.S. Proctor and P.J. Lynch: http://books.google.com/books?id=nQ3vLQkEWQMC&printsec=frontcover&dq=general+warbler+bill+shape#v=onepage&q&f=false • Bibby CJ, Burgess ND, Hill DA, Mustoe S, editors. 2000.
